occurrences.line_text: To saue him selfe from those his furious heats,
To saue her selfe, least that he did her slay:
Fro dangers dread his doubtfull life to saue;
To saue themselues, and scattered were abrode:
But saue my life, which lot before your foot doth lay.
I will it graunt, your hopelesse life to saue;
And what he did, he did him selfe to saue:
From which to thinke to saue himselfe, it booted not.
How to saue hole her hazarded estate;
Saue such as sudden rage him lent to smite,
Cryde out aloud for mercie him to saue;
She could or saue, or spill, whom she would hight.
Vppon that Carle, to saue his friend from ieopardy.
(Saue onely Glorianaes heauenly hew
All saue the shepheard, who for fell despight
How he might saue her life, if life did last;
To saue her chylde, which in misfortunes mouth was plaste.
The same is yonder Lady, whom high God did saue.
Thy life she saued by her gracious deed,
Her selfe not saued yet from daunger dred
To his owne loue his loialtie he saued:
And saued from his cruell villany.
Saued but two, yet in two yeares before,
Saued him selfe, but that he there him slew:
Of those, that hauing saued her from dying,
But euen that which thou sauedst, thine still to remaine?
To saueguard her, ywandred all alone;
A booke, wherein his Saueours testament
Whom false Duessa saues, and for
Satyrane saues the Squire of Dames
Fayre Britomart saues Amoret,
Belphebe saues from dread:
Defends him selfe, and saues his gotten pray.
Saues Terpine from the gallow tree,
Calidore saues from Maleffort,
Saues Serena, whilest Calepine
he saues, his loue doth misse.
Remembred he, ne car'd for his saufgard,
Then like a Lion, which hath long time saught
Had gathered Rew, and Sauine, and the flowre
And of rare beautie, sauing that askaunce
In sauing him from daungerous despaire
Throwes forth to men, sweet and well sauoured,
By which he saw the vgly monster plaine,
They saw so rudely falling to the ground,
Their bellies swolne he saw with fulnesse burst,
But when he saw his labour all was vaine,
But when he saw his threatning was but vaine,
Which when he saw, he burnt with gealous fire,
He saw diuided into double parts,
But when she saw the knight his speare aduaunce,
The Lady when she saw her champion fall,
I saw before mine eyes, if I were knowne to stray.
But when she saw her prayers nought preuaile,
And saw the Red-crosse, which the knight did beare,
Like euer saw. And there a noble crew
Inconstant man, that loued all he saw,
For death it was, when any good he saw,
Who when she saw Duessa sunny bright,
And him before, I saw with bitter eyes
But when she saw her offred sweets refused
So when he saw his flatt'ring arts to fayle,
Whose like he neuer saw, he durst not bide,
The Lyon whelpes she saw how he did beare,
But when he saw the Damsell passe away
His liuing like saw neuer liuing eye,
So daunted when the Geaunt saw the knight,
The wofull Dwarfe, which saw his maisters fall,
And saw the signes, that deadly tydings spake,
That when his deare Duessa heard, and saw
Whom these sad eyes saw nigh vnto deaths dore,
Whom when his Lady saw, to him she ran
More vgly shape yet neuer liuing creature saw.
So faire a creature yet saw neuer sunny day.
For neuer knight I saw in such misseeming plight.
That nought but death before his eyes he saw,
But when as none of them he saw him take,
Which when as Vna saw, through euery vaine
Which when the carle beheld, and saw his guest
By that, which lately hapned, Vna saw,
For God he often saw from heauens hight,
But when he saw them come, he did them still forsake.
Which when his pensiue Ladie saw from farre,
Since late she saw him fall before his enemy.
Tho when he saw no power might preuaile,
When gentle Vna saw the second fall
When now he saw himselfe so freshly reare,
She saw not stirre, off-shaking vaine affright,
She nigher drew, and saw that ioyous end:
Another said, he saw him moue his eyes indeed.
None but that saw (quoth he) would weene for troth,
Tho when as still he saw him towards pace,
And saw no meanes to scape, of shame affrayd,
Which when Sir Guyon saw, all were he wroth,
And saw it stirre: she left her percing launce,
Which when the Peasant saw, amazd he stood,
He saw from farre, or seemed for to see
Which when the Palmer saw, he loudly cryde,
Turning about he saw that wretched Squire,
That when the varlet heard and saw, streight way
When late he saw his Lord in heauy plight,
Wayting to passe, he saw whereas did swim
Which when farre off Cymochles heard, and saw,
But when he saw her toy, and gibe, and geare,
Such as he saw, she gan him lay before,
And vaine delight she saw he light did pas,
Whylest there the varlet stood, he saw from farre
The varlet saw, when to the flood he came,
Him when the old man saw, he wondred sore,
Yet sithens helpe, he saw, he needed more
Soone as he Guyon saw, in great affright
But whenas Mammon saw his purpose mist,
But when as earthly wight they present saw,
They neuer creature saw, that came that way.
Which whenas Guyon saw, he gan inquire,
Like euer saw, but they from hence were sold;
And looking downe, saw many damned wights,
Whom when the Palmer saw, abasht he was
Whom when Pyrrochles saw, inflam'd with rage,
When vnder him he saw his Lybian steed to praunce.
Which when his brother saw, fraught with great griefe
Als when his brother saw the red bloud rayle
Whom when the Palmer saw in such distresse,
For when Cymochles saw the fowle reproch,
Which when his german saw, the stony feare
And sword saw not, he wexed wondrous woe:
Which when he heard, and saw the tokens trew,
Which when they saw, they weened fowle reproch
Nigh to his vtmost date he saw proceed,
Yet life he saw, and felt his mightie maine,
And streight they saw the raging surges reard
On th'other side, they saw that perilous Rocke,
Which when she saw, she left her lockes vndight,
Eftsoones they saw an hideous hoast arrayd,
Whom such when Guyon saw, he drew him neare,
On which when gazing him the Palmer saw,
Which when his Palmer saw, he gan to feare
But when she saw them gone, she forward went,
On which she saw sixe knights, that did darraine
When Britomart him saw, she ran a pace
But for she saw him bent to cruell play,
But when she saw no helpe might him restore,
Whom when the Lady saw so faire a wight.
Tho when the Britonesse saw all the rest
On th'other side, they saw the warlike Mayd
Whose prowesse paragon saw neuer liuing wight.
Whose shape or person yet I neuer saw,
I in my fathers wondrous mirrhour saw,
That when old Glauce saw, for feare least blame
That secretly he saw, yet note discoure:
When the two fearefull women saw, they grew
I saw a Saxon Virgin, the which feld
She saw bestrowed all with rich aray
Saw neuer liuing eye more heauy sight,
Where when they saw that goodly boy, with blood
Soone as she Venus saw behind her backe,
Whom when as Venus saw so sore displeased,
Each shade she saw, and each noyse she did heare,
The fairest creature, that he euer saw,
But past awhile, when she fit season saw
Tho when all other helpes she saw to faile,
Sith him he saw still stronger grow through strife,
That her pursewed, saw with great remorse,
But that bold knight, whom ye pursuing saw
Which when she saw, more bent to eke my smartes,
That who so then her saw, would surely say,
But when he saw himselfe free from poursute,
And saw his drouer driue along the streame,
But when he saw that blazing beauties beame,
He therein saw that yrkesome sight, which smote
But when all this he nothing saw preuaile,
He else could doe, he saw himselfe esteemd,
And saw the fieldes of faire Scamander strowne
As Hellene, when she saw aloft appeare
And saw the wicked fire so furiously
At last when sorrow he saw booted nought,
Soone as the old man saw Sir Paridell,
Saw all this goodly sport, and grieued sore,
Which when Malbecco saw, out of his bush
Whom when the Gyaunt saw, he soone resinde
Which when she heard, and saw the ghastly fit,
Whom whenas Scudamour saw past the fire,
Did liuely seeme to tremble, wheh she saw
Yet liuing creature none she saw appeare:
In secret shade, and saw both first and last,
Of all those persons, which she saw without:
Ne liuing wight she saw in all that roome,
Soone as that virgin knight he saw in place,
She saw so rich and royally arayd,
Yet saw her not nor signe of her good speed,
I saw, why should I doubt to tell the same?
I saw (quoth she) a stranger knight, whose name
I saw him haue your Amoret at will,
I saw him kisse, I saw him her embrace,
I saw him kisse, I saw him her embrace,
I saw him sleepe with her all night his fill,
Which when their mother saw, she gan to dout
That when she saw, it did her much amate,
Which when she saw, downe on the bloudy plaine
When all men saw this sudden change of things,
Where when she saw that cruell war so ended,
When as he saw the mercilesse affray
There where he saw the valiant Triamond
All that her saw with wonder rauisht weare,
For soone as she them saw to discord set,
Which when that warriour saw, he said no more,
Who soone as she him saw approaching neare
At length when as he saw her hastie heat
Long since in that enchaunted glasse she saw.
Besides her modest countenance he saw
Whom when on ground she groueling saw to rowle,
Ne creature saw, but hearkned now and then
Which when she saw, with sodaine glauncing eye,
And eke by that he saw on euery tree,
Yet saw he often how he wexed glad,
And saw that all he said and did, was vaine,
Yet saw her forward still to make her flight,
Whom when she saw in wretched weedes disguiz'd,
Where when he saw the Prince in armour bright,
So faire, as euer yet saw liuing eie:
Saw comming home; all voide of doubtfull feare,
But saw him sencelesse by the Squire vpstaide,
Began to doubt, when she them saw embrace,
They saw together skirmishing, as seemed:
Whose like they neuer saw till that same houre:
Which when he saw, the glaiue which he did wield
Yet all those sights, and all that else I saw,
Whom when I saw with amiable grace
When as he saw me, maugre all his powre,
Her constant mind could moue at all he saw,
Ne euer euening saw, ne mornings ray,
She saw could ease his rankling maladie,
They saw it all, and present were in place;
Which when his mother saw, she in her mind
Yet since she saw the streight extremitie,
When as they saw a Squire in squallid weed,
Which when his Ladie saw, she follow'd fast,
When as he saw she should be cut in twaine,
Who when he saw it bootelesse to resist,
Where on the Bridge he ready armed saw
Which when the Pagan saw, he wexed wroth,
He saw no way, but close with him in hast;
Vppon the Castle wall, and when she saw
But when as yet she saw him to proceede,
They saw before them, far as they could vew,
Which when he saw, he greatly grew in rage,
Long wayted, saw his sudden desolation,
When Talus saw they all the field forsooke
And saw that boasters pride and gracelesse guile,
But now when Philtra saw my lands decay,
And in the midst of them he saw a Knight,
But when she saw at last, that he ne would
Soone as she saw him on the ground to grouell,
Whom when he saw before his foote prostrated,
He saw his senses straunge astonishment,
There entred in, he round about him saw
But when as yet she saw him not returne,
She saw it vaine to make there lenger stay,
But that she saw there present in her sight,
Whose like before she neuer saw nor red;
Which when she saw, her helmet she vnlaste,
All sodainely she saw transfigured
There present saw, each one of sence bereft,
Yet when she saw the heapes, which he did make,
Where when she saw that lothly vncouth sight,
Soone after these he saw another Knight,
At length he saw the hindmost ouertake
Where when they saw their foes dead out of doubt,
Soone as the infants sunlike shield they saw,
As this bold woman, when she saw that Damzell there.
Him when the damzell saw fast by her side,
But when the villaine saw her so affrayd,
Which when he saw, his yron man he sent,
For neuer saw they there the like array.
There as they entred at the Scriene, they saw
So did this mightie Ladie, when she saw
Though plaine she saw by all, that she did heare,
When one in armes she saw, began to fly;
Whom when his other fellowes saw, they fled
And euer ere he saw the stroke to land,
Which when the Lady from the Castle saw,
Now when they saw it falne, they eke him greeted all.
Whose vgly shape none euer saw, nor kend,
There he that Idoll saw of massy gold
Tho when she saw, that she was forst to fight,
Whom when he saw on ground, he was full glad,
Whom when she saw so ioyously come forth,
When first to Faery court he saw her wend,
They saw a Knight in daungerous distresse
Ye with those caytiues saw, Flourdelis hight,
When Artegall she saw in that array,
Againe whiles he him saw so ill bested,
Whom when he saw prostrated on the plaine,
Which when the people round about him saw,
When he him saw, for no demaunds he staide,
They saw that Carle from farre, with hand vnblest
But when Briana saw that drery stound,
But when he saw his foe before in vew,
And them beside a Ladie faire he saw,
Which when he saw, his hart was inly child
Him stedfastly he markt, and saw to bee
Which when I saw, as they me passed by,
Meane while his Ladie, which this outrage saw,
I neuer saw in any greater hope appeare.
These eyes him saw vpon the cold earth sprad,
Who when he saw his sonne so ill bedight,
Where when he saw his faire Priscilla by,
Since first he saw her, and did free from feare
Who nathelesse, when he the Lady saw
For pitty of his Dame, whom she saw so diseased.
And saw his carriage past that perill well,
He saw, the present mischiefe to redresse,
He saw his life powrd forth dispiteously:
Who euer, as he saw him nigh succeed,
But when the Saluage saw his labour vaine,
Gainst whom she saw no meanes to be defended,
Whom though he saw now somewhat ouerpast,
Whom when as Calepine saw so dismayd,
Ne euer saw faire guize, ne learned good,
Whom when the Saluage saw so sore distrest,
She saw now left, she cast to leaue the place,
Whom when her Host saw readie to depart,
Whom when the Hermite present saw in place,
Who when on ground they saw their fellow slaine,
He saw the ground all strow'd, and that same Knight
But when his foe he still so eger saw,
Which when the Ladie saw, with great affright
Whom when the Prince so deadly saw dismayd,
Whom when the Prince so felly saw to rage,
Whom when the Saluage saw from daunger free,
Where when he saw his fellow lifelesse ly,
So as they rode, he saw the way all dyde
Whom when as Turpin saw so loosely layd,
There when he saw those two so neare him stand,
In cases like, which when at last she saw,
And saw those villaines her so vildely vse,
And saw him selfe captiu'd, he was dismayd,
The faire Serena, when she saw him fall
The Squire him selfe when as he saw his Lord,
The greatest shame that euer eye yet saw?
When all his strokes he saw auoyded quite,
Which when the Lady saw, she cryde amaine;
Eftsoones he saw one with a naked knife
If such a beast they saw, which he had thether brought.
They answer'd him, that no such beast they saw,
Saw a faire damzell, which did weare a crowne
But why when I them saw, fled they away from me?
To reskue her, but when he saw the feend,
When he the beast saw ready now to rend
At last, when him she so importune saw,
But when she saw, through that small fauours gaine,
But when they saw her now reliu'd againe,
And saw his shepheards cottage spoyled quight,
Before I saw faire Pastorella dye.
These eyes saw die, and dearely did lament:
But when he saw the theeues, which did them keepe,
His hart gan fayle, albe he saw them all asleepe.
In which that rose she plainely saw displayd.
When she so faire a daughter saw suruiue,
Tho when the Beast saw, he mote nought auaile,
So rudely handled by her foe he sawe,
That if old sawes proue true (which God forbid)
That all those Ladies, which thou sawest late,
And sawst the secrets of the world vnmade,
Tell what thou saw'st, maulgre who so it heares.
Of Saxon kings, that haue with mightie hand
Against his Saxon foes in bloudy field to fight.
That Saxon kings his friendship shall intreat;
I saw a Saxon Virgin, the which feld
Of Saxon goods, emongst the which was seene
Which long'd to Angela, the Saxon Queene,
Of Saxons, whom he for his safetie imployes.
Shall well defend, and Saxons powre suppresse,
Shall stoutly him defeat, and thousand Saxons kill.
T'afflict the other Saxons vnsubdewd;
And to the Saxons ouer-giue their gouernment.
Ne shall the Saxons selues all peaceably
The other Saxons, which do for her sake
The Easterne Saxons from the Southerne ny,
Vntroubled night they say giues counsell best.
Wherein the Hermite dewly wont to say
And she coy lookes: so dainty they say maketh derth.
Say on Fradubio then, or man, or tree,
Sate in eternall night: nought could she say,
And thrise nine hundred Aues she was wont to say.
And sooth to say, why I left you so long,
Great Iunoes golden chaire, the which they say
All in a kirtle of discolourd say
And bad say on the secret of her hart.
Goe say, his foe thy shield with his doth beare.
And then to him these womanish words gan say;
Wherewith emmou'd, these bleeding words she gan to say.
Till gentle Vna thus to him gan say;
And pure vnspotted life: so well they say
And to her gossips gan in counsell say;
Thus gan to say. But eare he thus had said,
For may I boldly say, he surely is
Through fear and wonder, that he nought could say,
And say, that I not ouercome do dye,
Then made he sacred lawes, which some men say
Who brought with him the holy grayle, (they say)
Ne what to say, ne what to doe at all;
That is the Gulfe of Greedinesse, they say,
The constant paire heard all, that he did say,
There the wise Merlin whylome wont (they say)
It is an hideous hollow caue (they say)
The cause some say is this: A litle while
And sooth, men say that he was not the sonne
Did him, they say, forwarne through sacred spell.
Fiue dayes there be, since he (they say) was slaine,
Who in her sleepe (a wondrous thing to say)
There yet, some say, in secret he does ly,
And sooth it seemes they say: for he may not
In a strong rocky Caue, which is they say,
These twinnes, men say, (a thing far passing thought)
That who so then her saw, would surely say,
Ne cares, what men say of him ill or well;
Thereat Sir Satyrane gan smile, and say;
Except Cleopolis: so heard I say
False loue, why do men say, thou canst not see,
Yet durst he not against it doe or say,
From Limbo lake him late escaped sure would say.
Three nights in one, they say, that for her sake
As if in mind he somewhat had to say,
His garment neither was of silke nor say,
Of outrage for the words, which she heard say,
Seeing so faire indeede, as he did say,
This pretious ornament they say did make,
Was fostered by those Graces, (as they say)
But he nought car'd for all that they could say:
For ought that Glauce could or doe or say.
He wondred much. But th'other thus can say;
And eft againe deuiz'd some what to say,
When so he heard her say, eftsoones he brake
For ought that euer she could doe or say,
But for, they say, she hath both kinds in one,
So did he say: but I with murmure soft,
That euer she to me could say or doe,
Like as the mother of the Gods, they say,
Then this of Artegall, which here we haue to say.
But whether it be so or no, I can not say.
This doe I say, that what so good or ill
And little had for his excuse to say,
The cause, they say, of this her cruell hate,
What euer he shall like to doe or say.
Say on my souerayne Ladie, and be bold;
Say, and do all, that may thereto preuaile;
But he the man, that say or doe so dare,
Sadly she rode, and neuer word did say,
Ne drinke of wine, for wine they say is blood,
Say on (quoth he) the secret of your hart:
Vntill they both doe heare, what she to them will say.
Whom when they heard so say, they lookt about,
To all which cruell tyranny they say,
Like to the Thracian Tyrant, who they say
Nought feared they, what he could do, or say,
There they doe say, that she transformed was
But some doe say, it goeth downe to hell.
Vpon the righteous Themis: those they say
And sooth they say, that he was borne and bred
For they were all, they say, of purple hew,
Those he deuoures, they say, both flesh and bone:
That euer scap'd: for of a man they say
Whose euery act and word, that he did say,
It gladly did accept, as he did say.
Fearelesse, who ought did thinke, or ought did say,
But go thy waies to him, and fro me say,
And eke could doe, as well as say the same,
Till Mirabellaes fortunes I doe further say.
With which approching, thus he gan to say;
And let him rise. Then thus the Prince gan say;
But she for nought that he could say or doe,
In courtesie, and well could doe and say,
They say that Venus, when she did dispose
But all that euer he could doe or say,
Mongst which he found a sword of better say,
Now (sayd the Lady) draweth toward night,
With sober countenaunce thus to him sayd;
His error, and himselfe inclyning sayd;
Which when I wretch,---Not one word more she sayd
His craftie engin, and as he had sayd,
Yet him perforce restraynd, and to him doubtfull sayd.
Long trembling still he stood: at last thus sayd;
As to the Patrone of his life, thus sayd;
So straungely passioned, and to her gently sayd,
He then remembred well, that had bene sayd,
Who him auizing better, to him sayd;
That sayd, her round about she from her turnd,
But brusting forth in laughter, to her sayd;
And sayd, Sith then thou knowest all our griefe,
Of her vaine plaint, and to her scoffing sayd;
To find them out. Mote I (then laughing sayd
And turning backe to Scudamour, thus sayd;
And scoffing, thus vnto his mother sayd,
And maske her wounded mind, both did and sayd
And sayd, her loue to lose she was full loth,
Was tickled with delight, and iesting sayd;
Which when as Blandamour beheld, he sayd,
Ah gentle knight then false Duessa sayd,
Vile hag (sayd Scudamour) why dost thou lye?
